description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) is designed to be an entry point into the world of Microsoft certifications, validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on the knowledge required for the 98-368: MTA Mobility and Devices Fundamentals Exam. One will also focus on desktops, laptops, tablets, cell phones and other devices typically used by an end user because when one first transitions over to IT, one will typically be starting in a role as help desk or desktop support and will need to identify and resolve the issues of such devices. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Mobility and Devices Fundamentals - 98-368
subtitle: Mobility and Devices Fundamentals

180

And so, those are some of the things that

183
00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:54.220
Then, we've got an important section,

184
00:07:54.220 --> 00:07:55.440
more services are moving this way.

195

And then lastly, this one,

196

Enterprise Mobility is basically saying,

197

199

Right?

204
00:08:44.820 --> 00:08:47.990
How do we manage our own mobile devices?

205
00:08:47.990 --> 00:08:51.050
And how do we manage the ones that

206
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:53.550
So we get a chance to take a look

207
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:57.610
some of the solutions that we have, like
work folders and Azure remote apps and

208

technologies that can let us safely

209
00:09:02.950 --> 00:09:06.390

210
00:09:06.390 --> 00:09:08.330

stay tuned,

00:09:47.530 --> 00:09:49.564
we've got our episode starting up next.

226
00:09:49.564 --> 00:09:56.309
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to configure some of the common device options in a Windows desktop environment. Here they explain and demonstrate the benefits of using a Microsoft Account to login to all of your Windows devices. Also covered is the Control Panel and System options that give you the ability to adjust your system devices.
episodes.title: Configure Device Options
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.708 --> 00:00:16.387
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.387 --> 00:00:19.464
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
here with me today is Mr. Don Pezet.

4
00:00:19.464 --> 00:00:20.289
How's it going today, Don?

5
00:00:20.289 --> 00:00:21.369
>> It's going great, Daniel.

6
00:00:21.369 --> 00:00:24.066
Glad to be back on the show,
and excited to kick off

7
00:00:24.066 --> 00:00:28.420
the Microsoft Technology Associate for
the Mobility and Devices exam.

8
00:00:28.420 --> 00:00:31.010
This is, I know the exam
title's a little misleading,

9
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:33.290
but it's the Windows 8 exam really, right.

10
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:35.360
The Windows desktop operating system.

11
00:00:35.360 --> 00:00:39.210
And so we're gonna kick things off
right at the very beginning with

12
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:40.810
just getting logged into Windows.

13
00:00:40.810 --> 00:00:43.516
How Windows handles our user accounts
when we work with the system.

14
00:00:43.516 --> 00:00:46.828
So that's what we've got on the agenda
today, and it should be a pretty good run.

15
00:00:46.828 --> 00:00:50.259
All right, well let's start off just by
talking about one of the big differences

16
00:00:50.259 --> 00:00:52.190
that Microsoft introduced with Windows 8.

17
00:00:52.190 --> 00:00:55.010
Back in Windows 7,
when you logged into Windows,

18
00:00:55.010 --> 00:00:58.450
you logged in with what's
called a local user account.

19
00:00:58.450 --> 00:01:01.690
Every Windows machine has at
least one local user account.

20
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:04.552
That's a user that exists right
there on that machine, and

21
00:01:04.552 --> 00:01:07.083
not on any other machine that's out there,
right.

22
00:01:07.083 --> 00:01:09.715
So I might log in to my
desktop as Don Pezet.

23
00:01:10.750 --> 00:01:12.660
But then I go to Daniel's laptop and

24
00:01:12.660 --> 00:01:15.480
I can't log in,
cuz my user account doesn't exist there.

25
00:01:15.480 --> 00:01:17.390
Daniel has an account there,
but I don't, right.

26
00:01:17.390 --> 00:01:20.460
And if he comes to my laptop, I don't have
an account for him here either, right.

27
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:22.180
That's the idea behind a local account.

28
00:01:22.180 --> 00:01:25.510
It's just local to your
individual machine.

29
00:01:25.510 --> 00:01:29.460
But right now, there's a big push
to go towards cloud services.

30
00:01:29.460 --> 00:01:32.580
And with cloud services, it's kind of
neat because you can have a user account

31
00:01:32.580 --> 00:01:34.880
that isn't tied just to your machine.

32
00:01:34.880 --> 00:01:37.640
But is instead tied, well, to the cloud.

33
00:01:37.640 --> 00:01:41.720
So that you could login on any
machine with that cloud account.

34
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:43.770
And there's a couple of other
neat little benefits and

35
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:45.860
things that we'll talk
about a little bit later.

36
00:01:45.860 --> 00:01:49.840
But, for the local account, that's
the one that you're guaranteed to have.

37
00:01:49.840 --> 00:01:52.070
Everybody's gonna have at
least one local account.

38
00:01:52.070 --> 00:01:54.584
It's created during the installation
of Windows, and you're gonna have it.

39
00:01:54.584 --> 00:01:56.750
Now you might not know that.

40
00:01:56.750 --> 00:02:00.970
You might have purchased a laptop
from Dell or a desktop from HP or

41
00:02:00.970 --> 00:02:04.730
Asus or whoever, Lenovo,
whoever it is that you bought from.

42
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:07.370
And when you turn on that PC,
it might fire up and

43
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.089
go right to the Windows desktop,
and you're ready to work, okay.

44
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:13.638
A lot of hardware vendors will
set up a default account for you.

45
00:02:13.638 --> 00:02:16.728
But you can always go back in and create
your own accounts, add more people or

46
00:02:16.728 --> 00:02:19.596
remove people, you can do all sorts
of neat things there, all right.

47
00:02:19.596 --> 00:02:20.981
So let me show you that process and

48
00:02:20.981 --> 00:02:24.140
how we manage these user
accounts inside of Windows.

49
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:26.780
I've got a desktop fired up here,
this is a Windows 8 machine, and

50
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:30.780
it's just a base install of Windows 8,
nothing too fancy on it.

51
00:02:30.780 --> 00:02:35.100
And if I swipe up or hit my up arrow
on the keyboard, I get my login screen.

52
00:02:35.100 --> 00:02:37.800
Now, when I look at this login screen,
see how its got my name right here?

53
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:40.540
Just Don Pezet, that's it, and
it's asking for a password.

54
00:02:40.540 --> 00:02:44.890
I don't have a photo loaded for my account
yet, so I just have a person's face there,

55
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:48.190
a stick man, whatever, and
I can get logged in, right.

56
00:02:48.190 --> 00:02:51.400
If you installed Windows yourself, it
asked you for a password at that time, and

57
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:54.770
so you can provide that password and
you get logged in.

58
00:02:54.770 --> 00:02:56.920
I'm logging in with a local account.

59
00:02:56.920 --> 00:02:59.620
Now, how do I know it's a local account?

60
00:02:59.620 --> 00:03:02.350
Well, I know it's local
cuz all I saw was a name.

61
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:05.790
WIth a cloud account, right, an account
that's hosted out there on the Internet,

62
00:03:05.790 --> 00:03:09.040
you're usually going to have an address
that looks more like an email address.

63
00:03:09.040 --> 00:03:13.956
So it'll be something, name at and
a domain, donpezet@hotmail.com,

64
00:03:13.956 --> 00:03:15.991
something like that, right.

65
00:03:15.991 --> 00:03:17.460
That's what you're gonna see.

66
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:20.370
But on a local account,
you'll typically just see your name.

67
00:03:20.370 --> 00:03:23.240
Just like I did right there,
that's kind of the typical environment.

68
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:26.660
Now, I keep saying typical,
you actually can change the way they look.

69
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:30.260
So you could have a local account
that did look like a cloud account.

70
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:33.060
So it's not necessarily set in stone
that that's the way that it works.

71
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:35.523
But, it's usually a pretty
good assumption, right.

72
00:03:35.523 --> 00:03:36.840
Now when we log in to Windows,

73
00:03:36.840 --> 00:03:39.810
we know who we're logged in as if
we look at our start menu, right.

74
00:03:39.810 --> 00:03:42.380
So, I can see Don Pezet right there,
there's that same kind

75
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:45.300
of stick man figure cuz I haven't loaded
a photo from my account yet, right.

76
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:50.390
Now if I wanna take a look at
what accounts are actually local,

77
00:03:50.390 --> 00:03:52.320
I wanna be certain, I don't wanna guess.

78
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:55.140
I wanna know,
is this account local or not, right.

79
00:03:55.140 --> 00:03:57.990
We can take a look at the local
account database right inside of our

80
00:03:57.990 --> 00:03:59.240
Windows Control Panel.

81
00:03:59.240 --> 00:04:01.780
So there's a few different ways to
get to it, but we can jump in and

82
00:04:01.780 --> 00:04:03.550
take a look at our local user accounts.

83
00:04:03.550 --> 00:04:06.330
And the reason why most of
us are gonna care about this

84
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:10.470
is because you may need
more than one user account.

85
00:04:10.470 --> 00:04:13.350
Having more than one user account
on your system can be really handy

86
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:14.700
if you share your computer.

87
00:04:14.700 --> 00:04:18.070
Now I'm kinda stingy with my laptop,
I really don't share it with anybody.

88
00:04:18.070 --> 00:04:20.250
But Daniel,
do you share yours with anybody?

89
00:04:20.250 --> 00:04:23.010
>> Yeah Don, I don't share this
computer out specifically.

90
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:26.860
But we do have a home PC where my wife and
myself, we share that, and

91
00:04:26.860 --> 00:04:28.480
we have an account for each one of us.

92
00:04:28.480 --> 00:04:30.670
That way I'm not stomping
all over her settings,

93
00:04:30.670 --> 00:04:32.470
she's not stomping all over mine.

94
00:04:32.470 --> 00:04:35.375
I have the browsers and
the home pages that I like, and

95
00:04:35.375 --> 00:04:39.331
I have my desktop background the way
I like it, font size all that stuff.

96
00:04:39.331 --> 00:04:43.408
And that all comes from being able to
login as myself, and my wife gets the same

97
00:04:43.408 --> 00:04:47.712
kind of creature feature as well, so
it's kind of nice to have multiple logins.

98
00:04:47.712 --> 00:04:49.130
>> Yeah, and those personal settings,

99
00:04:49.130 --> 00:04:51.310
that's really what
multiple logins are for.

100
00:04:51.310 --> 00:04:53.980
If you don't need personal settings,
you could just share the same account, and

101
00:04:53.980 --> 00:04:55.500
then you don't worry about
user accounts at all.

102
00:04:55.500 --> 00:04:57.860
I know a lot of people set their
computers to automatically login.

103
00:04:57.860 --> 00:05:00.800
They never even see their account,
which is not the greatest idea but

104
00:05:00.800 --> 00:05:01.740
you can do it.

105
00:05:01.740 --> 00:05:05.520
But let's say for me,
accessing the desktop is really important.

106
00:05:05.520 --> 00:05:08.489
So I start moving my desktop icons around,
and

107
00:05:08.489 --> 00:05:11.240
maybe I resize that one
to be a larger icon.

108
00:05:11.240 --> 00:05:15.251
And Mail is less important for me,
so I resize it to make it smaller.

109
00:05:15.251 --> 00:05:18.195
So, as we start changing things and
manipulating it,

110
00:05:18.195 --> 00:05:20.950
we're making the environment
convenient for us.

111
00:05:20.950 --> 00:05:23.370
We're making the computer
work the way we want it to.

112
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:25.940
But if you share the computer
with other people,

113
00:05:25.940 --> 00:05:30.280
it may not work the way that they want it
to, right, so they want separate settings.

114
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:31.430
You also might want privacy.

115
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:33.980
I might have documents that I don't
want to share with somebody, and so

116
00:05:33.980 --> 00:05:38.370
I want my own separate account so
that we can keep those things separate.

117
00:05:38.370 --> 00:05:39.250
Or, you might have children.

118
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:41.680
If you have children that
are gonna be using your computer,

119
00:05:41.680 --> 00:05:44.300
Windows has parental controls
that you can enable.

120
00:05:44.300 --> 00:05:47.293
And with parental controls, you can
restrict things like Internet access and

121
00:05:47.293 --> 00:05:50.120
other abilities that
they have on the machine.

122
00:05:50.120 --> 00:05:52.800
And you don't want to restrict your
account, you want to restrict theirs, so

123
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:55.050
you use separate accounts for
that, all right.

124
00:05:55.050 --> 00:05:57.350
So to manage user accounts in Windows,

125
00:05:57.350 --> 00:05:59.010
we're gonna have to jump
into our control settings.

126
00:05:59.010 --> 00:06:00.640
So I'm gonna start by
bringing up my charms bar.

127
00:06:00.640 --> 00:06:03.270
Now if you haven't worked with Windows
8 a lot, the way we get to that is

128
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:07.350
on a touchscreen, you swipe in
from the right side of the screen.

129
00:06:07.350 --> 00:06:09.660
If you don't have a touchscreen,

130
00:06:09.660 --> 00:06:13.100
you can just move your mouse over
to the right side of your screen.

131
00:06:13.100 --> 00:06:16.560
And if you let it float there for
a second, the charms bar will appear, so

132
00:06:16.560 --> 00:06:18.210
you just have to be a little patient.

133
00:06:18.210 --> 00:06:20.360
Or you can hit Windows
key+C on your keyboard.

134
00:06:20.360 --> 00:06:23.900
All three methods will get you
into this charms bar right here.

135
00:06:23.900 --> 00:06:26.470
And once we're in the charms bar,
we're gonna jump into settings.

136
00:06:26.470 --> 00:06:28.520
And inside of your settings,
you'll see a few options.

137
00:06:28.520 --> 00:06:32.710
The one I want is hidden way down here
at the bottom, Change PC settings.

138
00:06:32.710 --> 00:06:36.550
So I'm gonna hit that, and then we'll
jump into our primary PC settings.

139
00:06:36.550 --> 00:06:39.010
Now from here, we're looking for
user accounts.

140
00:06:39.010 --> 00:06:42.690
And so you'll see PC and devices,
and then accounts right here.

141
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:45.570
And this is where we can see what
account we're logged in as, and

142
00:06:45.570 --> 00:06:47.970
we can see other accounts, all right.

143
00:06:47.970 --> 00:06:50.850
Now notice on my account,
if I had any doubt, this resolves it.

144
00:06:50.850 --> 00:06:52.880
It tells me this is a Local Account.

145
00:06:52.880 --> 00:06:55.810
So if we're not sure if it's local,
now we know.

146
00:06:55.810 --> 00:06:58.480
Or if it's a cloud account,
it would tell us that right here.

147
00:06:58.480 --> 00:07:01.290
In fact, it's encouraging me
to switch to a cloud account.

148
00:07:01.290 --> 00:07:03.360
It's saying sign in with
a Microsoft account,

149
00:07:03.360 --> 00:07:05.100
because there's certain
benefits that you get.

150
00:07:05.100 --> 00:07:07.567
I'm gonna talk about those later,
all right.

151
00:07:07.567 --> 00:07:10.747
But as far as a local account,
I can see my account right here and

152
00:07:10.747 --> 00:07:13.447
we could even create an account picture or
whatever,

153
00:07:13.447 --> 00:07:16.270
if we wanted to start customizing that for
us.

154
00:07:16.270 --> 00:07:18.640
But if I want to create more accounts for
my family,

155
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:22.730
then I can go over here to other accounts
and we can start adding more in, right.

156
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:26.060
So maybe I do want Daniel to have
an account on here, so I can punch it in.

157
00:07:26.060 --> 00:07:28.281
If he has a cloud account,
we can use that, right,

158
00:07:28.281 --> 00:07:29.842
there's that convenience again.

159
00:07:29.842 --> 00:07:33.268
Or way down here,
I can create a child's account, or

160
00:07:33.268 --> 00:07:36.430
I can sign in without a Microsoft account.

161
00:07:36.430 --> 00:07:38.246
That is another local account.

162
00:07:38.246 --> 00:07:40.110
So if I want another local account,

163
00:07:40.110 --> 00:07:43.040
choose to sign in without
a Microsoft account, all right.

164
00:07:43.040 --> 00:07:45.660
Now it's gonna tell me about
some of those benefits, right.

165
00:07:45.660 --> 00:07:48.432
Why I might want to go to a Microsoft
account versus a local account.

166
00:07:48.432 --> 00:07:51.372
But I'm gonna stick with local for
right now, and I'm gonna go and

167
00:07:51.372 --> 00:07:52.221
get that created.

168
00:07:52.221 --> 00:07:56.871
So I'll create an account for Daniel and
get this punched in the system.

169
00:07:56.871 --> 00:08:01.267
I'm just putting a user name and
a password, a super secure password.

170
00:08:01.267 --> 00:08:03.007
And we'll get that put in place.

171
00:08:03.007 --> 00:08:05.140
And it's asking me again if he's a child.

172
00:08:05.140 --> 00:08:06.771
Right, well, at heart.

173
00:08:06.771 --> 00:08:08.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> Daniel, I imagine.

174
00:08:08.280 --> 00:08:12.220
But no, this would be if I wanna have
those parental controls in place,

175
00:08:12.220 --> 00:08:13.919
I could turn those on,
I'm gonna leave that off.

176
00:08:14.960 --> 00:08:17.170
All right,
now I got another account, right.

177
00:08:17.170 --> 00:08:18.850
I've got that Daniel Lowrie account.

178
00:08:18.850 --> 00:08:23.260
And when I go to log in to the system,
his account is separate from mine.

179
00:08:23.260 --> 00:08:25.050
Right, two different accounts.

180
00:08:25.050 --> 00:08:30.610
If I jump back to my desktop, this is
the default Windows 8 desktop right here.

181
00:08:30.610 --> 00:08:33.240
Nothing too fancy, just these orange bars,

182
00:08:33.240 --> 00:08:38.180
and if I change that wallpaper,
I'm gonna personalize this a little bit.

183
00:08:38.180 --> 00:08:41.870
Let's go with something crazy here, right.

184
00:08:41.870 --> 00:08:42.740
Some kind of blue lines.

185
00:08:42.740 --> 00:08:44.290
That's profound.

186
00:08:44.290 --> 00:08:45.770
I imagine it's art.

187
00:08:45.770 --> 00:08:46.763
>> Very transcendental.

188
00:08:46.763 --> 00:08:48.330
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I feel at peace

189
00:08:48.330 --> 00:08:49.568
with my computer now.

190
00:08:49.568 --> 00:08:52.280
>> [LAUGH] Serenity Now
>> So now that I've got that set,

191
00:08:52.280 --> 00:08:53.480
that's kinda how I want it.

192
00:08:53.480 --> 00:08:55.940
And you guys saw on the Start menu,
how I moved it so

193
00:08:55.940 --> 00:09:00.090
the Desktop was the first icon, and
Mail was more, that's how I want it.

194
00:09:00.090 --> 00:09:03.710
But we can switch and
log in as Daniel, and

195
00:09:03.710 --> 00:09:06.480
it should be the way that he wants it,
okay?

196
00:09:06.480 --> 00:09:10.190
Now to switch to Daniel, I can click on
my user name here in the Start menu, and

197
00:09:10.190 --> 00:09:15.780
if I go to Sign out, I can sign out
as me and then sign in as Daniel.

198
00:09:15.780 --> 00:09:18.820
Or I can just choose Daniel
right here from the list.

199
00:09:18.820 --> 00:09:21.630
And this will do what's
called fast user switching.

200
00:09:21.630 --> 00:09:22.290
Okay?

201
00:09:22.290 --> 00:09:25.950
When you do fast user switching,
you don't actually log out.

202
00:09:25.950 --> 00:09:30.700
I'm still logged into the computer,
but now Daniel's logging in also.

203
00:09:30.700 --> 00:09:32.530
And since this is the first
time he's logging in,

204
00:09:32.530 --> 00:09:34.500
I'm seeing the New Profile Wizard.

205
00:09:34.500 --> 00:09:37.995
It actually goes through a process in the
background where it builds what's called

206
00:09:37.995 --> 00:09:38.960
a use profile.

207
00:09:38.960 --> 00:09:42.560
And the profile is where
all your stuff is stored.

208
00:09:42.560 --> 00:09:46.710
Your documents, your Internet Explorer
favorites, what wallpaper you chose,

209
00:09:46.710 --> 00:09:48.750
any preferences you have in the system,

210
00:09:48.750 --> 00:09:50.760
they're all stored as
part of your profile.

211
00:09:50.760 --> 00:09:54.130
And Daniel will have
a separate profile from me.

212
00:09:54.130 --> 00:09:56.730
And when it finally logs in,
here we go, it just logged in,

213
00:09:56.730 --> 00:09:58.610
we'll see he's got the default profile.

214
00:09:58.610 --> 00:10:02.840
He sees that orange background, with
the pyramids, and if he goes to the Start

215
00:10:02.840 --> 00:10:08.460
menu, he sees Mail is nice and big,
and Desktop is small down here, right?

216
00:10:08.460 --> 00:10:12.410
It's all back to the default,
these are his settings, but

217
00:10:12.410 --> 00:10:16.510
if I switch back to me,
my settings are still there.

218
00:10:16.510 --> 00:10:17.410
I can switch back to me.

219
00:10:17.410 --> 00:10:21.820
And here I am, and the settings
are back to the way that I want them.

220
00:10:21.820 --> 00:10:26.170
All right, that's the neat part about

269
00:11:55.660 --> 00:11:59.990
And if I go to View Details, I can see any
updates that have already been installed.

270
00:11:59.990 --> 00:12:01.320
And so it's gonna lay those out.

271
00:12:01.320 --> 00:12:03.040
Or if it found updates,
it'll give me details there.

272
00:12:03.040 --> 00:12:05.860
But here I'm seeing all the updates that
are already installed and, sure enough,

273
00:12:05.860 --> 00:12:07.610
I'm pretty well patched.

274
00:12:07.610 --> 00:12:08.860
There's a lot of updates here.

275
00:12:08.860 --> 00:12:12.170
Way down here at the bottom,
I have some optional ones, though.

276
00:12:12.170 --> 00:12:14.570
These are ones that they're
not even recommended.

277
00:12:14.570 --> 00:12:18.005
They're just optional I can get
them if I want, like Skype for

278
00:12:18.005 --> 00:12:20.665
Windows which is blocked out for
some reason.

279
00:12:20.665 --> 00:12:22.955
And Silverlight,
I can choose to install that if I want.

280
00:12:22.955 --> 00:12:27.955
But all of these other updates
installed on their own, so I'm up and

281
00:12:27.955 --> 00:12:29.440
going, and we're in business.

282
00:12:29.440 --> 00:12:32.930
So, that's kinda how this works for
our basic Windows updates.

283
00:12:32.930 --> 00:12:36.190
But that's not the only type of
update that we need to be aware of.

284
00:12:36.190 --> 00:12:39.580
There are some other ones
like hardware updates.

285
00:12:39.580 --> 00:12:42.540
You might have device drivers for
your system.

286
00:12:42.540 --> 00:12:46.965
When you take a laptop like mine, it's got
a display adapter that renders the screen,

287
00:12:46.965 --> 00:12:51.465
its got a sound card that renders
the audio, its got keyboard touchpad,

288
00:12:51.465 --> 00:12:53.650
its got all these different
hardware components.

289
00:12:53.650 --> 00:12:55.940
And those hardware components
are kind of important, for

290
00:12:55.940 --> 00:12:57.360
us to interact with the computer.

291
00:12:57.360 --> 00:13:00.090
They have drivers, and
the drivers get updates.

292
00:13:00.090 --> 00:13:04.810
So sometimes those hardware vendors
partner with Microsoft, and

293
00:13:04.810 --> 00:13:06.800
you can get those updates
through Microsoft.

294
00:13:06.800 --> 00:13:09.060
And so you might see an update for
your network card, but

295
00:13:09.060 --> 00:13:10.620
a lot of vendors don't do that.

296
00:13:10.620 --> 00:13:12.640
So don't forget to update
your hardware drivers.

297
00:13:12.640 --> 00:13:14.890
You might need to go to Dell, or HP, or

298
00:13:14.890 --> 00:13:17.980
whoever does you bought your
laptop through, Lenovo, whoever.

299
00:13:17.980 --> 00:13:20.950
And they'll have updates for
you to download and install, there, too,

300
00:13:20.950 --> 00:13:21.870
on the driver side.

301
00:13:21.870 --> 00:13:24.160
So those are some of the other
updates that are available.

302
00:13:25.610 --> 00:13:28.130
But sometimes they do come through
Windows update, and you do have it there.

303
00:13:30.120 --> 00:13:31.860
The other thing worth mentioning,

304
00:13:31.860 --> 00:13:35.230
is there's another type
of update in Windows 8.

305
00:13:35.230 --> 00:13:36.950
So it's new one that was introduced.

306
00:13:36.950 --> 00:13:40.670
This Windows update that I just showed you
guys, that's been in Windows for awhile.

307
00:13:40.670 --> 00:13:42.530
You remember, Daniel,
when was that first introduce?

308
00:13:42.530 --> 00:13:44.455
>> I wanna say XP.

309
00:13:44.455 --> 00:13:51.264
>> [CROSSTALK] So
that feature's been around a long time,

310
00:13:51.264 --> 00:13:56.303
but what about these new modern UI apps?

311
00:13:56.303 --> 00:14:00.150
>> Our modern UI apps, these apps
that are part of our start screen.

312
00:14:00.150 --> 00:14:03.240
These guys are a little bit different,
they're not like normal programs.

313
00:14:03.240 --> 00:14:06.310
Because normally,
we get them from the Microsoft store.

314
00:14:06.310 --> 00:14:08.300
I'm not going to a website downloading and
installing them,

315
00:14:08.300 --> 00:14:12.930
I'm going to the Microsoft store and
installing them, and where is my icon for

316
00:14:12.930 --> 00:14:13.820
the Microsoft store?

317
00:14:13.820 --> 00:14:17.580
Have I, oh, actually I think it's
this big advertisement, right here.

318
00:14:17.580 --> 00:14:19.480
So here's the Microsoft store, for me.

319
00:14:19.480 --> 00:14:22.060
And if I jump into the Microsoft store,
I can go and browse for apps, and

320
00:14:22.060 --> 00:14:23.640
find them and download them.

321
00:14:23.640 --> 00:14:25.760
Well, the cool thing
about the Windows store,

322
00:14:25.760 --> 00:14:28.890
is that it can update your apps for you.

323
00:14:28.890 --> 00:14:32.930
So, if you download your app here from the
store, and a new version of it comes out.

324
00:14:32.930 --> 00:14:34.810
The store can download the update.

325
00:14:34.810 --> 00:14:37.210
I install third party software myself,
right, so

326
00:14:37.210 --> 00:14:39.480
like on this machine I installed
a program called Wireshark.

327
00:14:40.520 --> 00:14:43.171
Wireshark, I went to their website,
wireshark.org, I download it and

328
00:14:43.171 --> 00:14:44.350
I installed it.

329
00:14:44.350 --> 00:14:47.420
If a new version comes out,
I don't know about it.

330
00:14:47.420 --> 00:14:50.790
So I have to go and find out about
the update, and install it myself.

331
00:14:50.790 --> 00:14:54.000
Or if I run the program, I think it does
its own little check, and it'll tell me

332
00:14:54.000 --> 00:14:58.090
there's a new version, but that doesn't
happen until I run the program.

333
00:14:58.090 --> 00:15:00.917
So I might be months out-of-date just
because I haven't run the program, and

334
00:15:00.917 --> 00:15:01.560
I don't know it.

335
00:15:02.660 --> 00:15:06.710
But with the Windows store,
it's actually checking your app status for

336
00:15:06.710 --> 00:15:10.920
you in the background, and so
it can do updates here too.

337
00:15:10.920 --> 00:15:13.010
And the way to see that If
you're on a touch screen,

338
00:15:13.010 --> 00:15:15.160
you can swipe down from the top.

339
00:15:15.160 --> 00:15:17.920
But on a regular desktop,
if you just right-click up here

340
00:15:17.920 --> 00:15:20.580
towards the top of the screen,
you'll get the pop-down.

341
00:15:20.580 --> 00:15:22.990
So, this is what you'd see
if you swipe down also.

342
00:15:22.990 --> 00:15:27.210
And in here, it's designed so
you can kind of browse and find apps, but

343
00:15:27.210 --> 00:15:29.230
you've also got the Your apps button.

344
00:15:29.230 --> 00:15:33.220
And when you choose that, it will show
the apps that you've installed from

345
00:15:33.220 --> 00:15:35.940
the Windows store, and
you can see I haven't installed any.

346
00:15:35.940 --> 00:15:36.990
I'm not signed in.

347
00:15:36.990 --> 00:15:39.220
But you'll see the apps
that you've installed, and

348
00:15:39.220 --> 00:15:42.430
if there's an update available
you can click Update.

349
00:15:42.430 --> 00:15:44.840
And it knocks out and
just gets it done and taken care of and

350
00:15:44.840 --> 00:15:46.940
it'll do that on its own
in the background too.

351
00:15:46.940 --> 00:15:51.160
So it's a different type of update that
happens for these apps right here.

352
00:15:51.160 --> 00:15:55.603
These ones that are kind of built into
the system that are right here and

353
00:15:55.603 --> 00:15:57.951
get updates pretty routinely also.

354
00:15:57.951 --> 00:16:01.318
One last thing,
I wanna mention on Windows updates.

355
00:16:01.318 --> 00:16:04.702
If you're in a business environment,
and so you've got

356
00:16:04.702 --> 00:16:09.357
system administrators that are managing
hundred of thousands of computers,

357
00:16:09.357 --> 00:16:14.730
there's actually another product out there
called the Windows Server Update Service.

358
00:16:14.730 --> 00:16:18.160
WSUS is what it is.

359
00:16:18.160 --> 00:16:22.990
And it allows a company to set up
their own Microsoft Update server.

360
00:16:22.990 --> 00:16:27.610
So when I went into Windows Updates here,
when I went into my settings and

361
00:16:27.610 --> 00:16:31.660
dug down into my PC Settings and
went into Update, went in here.

362
00:16:31.660 --> 00:16:34.370
This is reaching out to Microsoft,
reaching out to the servers that are out

363
00:16:34.370 --> 00:16:37.030
there in Microsoft's data center and
looking for updates.

364
00:16:37.030 --> 00:16:40.240
A company can set up their own server, and

365
00:16:40.240 --> 00:16:43.250
you can reach out and
check with your company instead.

366
00:16:43.250 --> 00:16:44.990
Now, why would we do that?

367
00:16:44.990 --> 00:16:47.920
Sometimes companies need to have
control of what updates you get.

368
00:16:47.920 --> 00:16:51.510
There might be an update that comes
out that breaks a program you run.

369
00:16:51.510 --> 00:16:53.360
You see that with the new versions
of Internet Explorer a lot.

370
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:57.030
You might have a program that runs
great in Internet Explorer 10, and

371
00:16:57.030 --> 00:16:58.910
then in Internet Explorer 11 it doesn't.

372
00:16:58.910 --> 00:17:01.210
The website doesn't render or
whatever, it's broken.

373
00:17:01.210 --> 00:17:04.580
So a company might choose to
withhold Internet Explorer 11.

374
00:17:04.580 --> 00:17:07.740
Well, they need to do that
across the whole company.

375
00:17:07.740 --> 00:17:12.320
So, in an enterprise environment they
can actually change these settings and

376
00:17:12.320 --> 00:17:14.840
make it mandatory across their PCs.

377
00:17:14.840 --> 00:17:16.810
So, if you come into these settings and

378
00:17:16.810 --> 00:17:19.830
this says the settings are managed
by a system administrator.

379
00:17:19.830 --> 00:17:22.545
Or controlled by your organization,
and it won't let you change anything,

380
00:17:22.545 --> 00:17:24.020
that's a great example of that, right?

381
00:17:24.020 --> 00:17:28.050
That you can't change it, because your
company is controlling it, all right?

382
00:17:28.050 --> 00:17:31.160
On your home computer,
you have full control, it's your computer.

383
00:17:31.160 --> 00:17:33.170
But on a work computer you probably won't.

384
00:17:33.170 --> 00:17:37.120
Expect to see that, where you can't go
in and change these options, all right?

385
00:17:37.120 --> 00:17:40.210
And that's because they
need to ensure that

386
00:17:40.210 --> 00:17:42.470
thousands of computers
are all kept up to date.

387
00:17:42.470 --> 00:17:47.335
Not worried about one computer,
they're worried about thousands, and so,

388
00:17:47.335 --> 00:17:49.777
mandatorily setting those settings.

389
00:17:49.777 --> 00:17:50.775
That's a terrible sentence.

390
00:17:50.775 --> 00:17:53.318
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, forcing those settings out,

391
00:17:53.318 --> 00:17:56.340
there we go,
is the best way to guarantee that for

392
00:17:56.340 --> 00:17:59.165
a company, so
you may see that out and about.

393
00:17:59.165 --> 00:18:01.736
>> Oh, yeah, I've definitely had
my fair share of that business,

394
00:18:01.736 --> 00:18:03.246
especially when it came to browsers.

395
00:18:03.246 --> 00:18:06.261
In a company Don and
I both have worked for in the past,

396
00:18:06.261 --> 00:18:09.860
there was a lot of website
usage with third party vendors.

397
00:18:09.860 --> 00:18:10.830
Now, third party vendor,

398
00:18:10.830 --> 00:18:14.590
a new version of maybe Internet Explorer
would come out, right?

399
00:18:14.590 --> 00:18:16.650
And we would push that new
version of Internet Explorer.

400
00:18:16.650 --> 00:18:19.700
We knew that all our
in-house apps worked fine.

401
00:18:19.700 --> 00:18:22.620
But their third party vendors,
they had yet to upgrade,

402
00:18:22.620 --> 00:18:24.660
make sure all their apps would work.

403
00:18:24.660 --> 00:18:27.730
So what would happen, people would call
and say I'm trying to get to such and

404
00:18:27.730 --> 00:18:30.310
such a website, and
it's not working correctly.

405
00:18:30.310 --> 00:18:32.500
Things aren't being displayed properly.

406
00:18:32.500 --> 00:18:34.810
And we would try to figure out,
maybe there's a setting we can move.

407
00:18:34.810 --> 00:18:38.030
But really it all boiled down
to is they were not up to

408
00:18:38.030 --> 00:18:41.760
date as we were with our apps, so
we would have to roll them back.

409
00:18:41.760 --> 00:18:45.210
And we'd have to make a separate group to
put them in and say, okay, they don't need

410
00:18:45.210 --> 00:18:50.720
to be forced into the new version of this
software because it causes them problems.

411
00:18:50.720 --> 00:18:53.860
It can be a bit of an administrative
nightmare for us as admins, but

412
00:18:53.860 --> 00:18:57.280
it's just one of those things you
gotta live with and it does happen.

413
00:18:57.280 --> 00:18:58.940
So, yeah, Don is correct.

414
00:18:58.940 --> 00:19:03.524
Every now and then a update will,
quote unquote, break things.

415
00:19:03.524 --> 00:19:06.934
But it's probably not, I mean it
does happen, it does break things.

416
00:19:06.934 --> 00:19:10.970
But when that happens, it's rare, it's
not something that happens all the time.

417
00:19:10.970 --> 00:19:12.840
I did see a lot of people that thought,

418
00:19:12.840 --> 00:19:15.640
I'll just stop doing updates
because it breaks everything.

419
00:19:15.640 --> 00:19:17.830
Well, that is not the best policy.

420
00:19:17.830 --> 00:19:18.740
Can they break stuff?

421
00:19:18.740 --> 00:19:21.040
Yes, it does happen from time to time.

422
00:19:21.040 --> 00:19:24.750
But us as your administrators, or you
as one day you may become one was well,

423
00:19:24.750 --> 00:19:27.140
you go in, you find out what the problem
is, you get things get fixed.

424
00:19:27.140 --> 00:19:30.000
Microsoft will then release probably
a new patch that fixes what

425
00:19:30.000 --> 00:19:31.758
was broken with the old patch.

426
00:19:31.758 --> 00:19:35.320
[LAUGH] It's a never-ending circle with
the patching, that's for sure, right, Don?

427
00:19:35.320 --> 00:19:37.030
>> Yeah, and it generates support tickets.

428
00:19:37.030 --> 00:19:39.865
Now you get your whole team involved so
it's an actual cost to the company.

429
00:19:39.865 --> 00:19:41.692
So we definitely want to be aware that.

430
00:19:41.692 --> 00:19:46.234
It's a real issue,
that companies are going to have.

431
00:19:46.234 --> 00:19:47.555
In the background you hear, Daniel,

432
00:19:47.555 --> 00:19:49.661
I'm trying to sign in with my
Microsoft account real quick so

433
00:19:49.661 --> 00:19:51.710
I can kinda show them that app
screen that was empty for me.

434
00:19:51.710 --> 00:19:53.590
Here we go, let me show you guys this.

435
00:19:53.590 --> 00:19:57.710
So I just signed into the Windows Store
with my own account so

436
00:19:57.710 --> 00:19:58.980
I could see some apps.

437
00:19:58.980 --> 00:20:03.120
And so here you can see apps that
I've either installed before or

438
00:20:03.120 --> 00:20:04.440
purchased before.

439
00:20:04.440 --> 00:20:07.100
And so, as you look through here you'll
see the different apps that are a part of

440
00:20:07.100 --> 00:20:09.330
it, and whether they're available or not.

441
00:20:09.330 --> 00:20:11.260
And well,
a lot of these are saying not available,

442
00:20:11.260 --> 00:20:13.890
which is probably cuz I haven't
logged out and logged back in yet.

443
00:20:13.890 --> 00:20:15.420
But if there's an update available,

444
00:20:15.420 --> 00:20:17.710
it'll actually show up right here
in the very beginning so you know.

445
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:19.630
And there'll be an Update All button.

446
00:20:19.630 --> 00:20:22.400
You just hit that and it knocks thorough
that update and get's it take care of.

447
00:20:22.400 --> 00:20:24.880
So, a lot of different excuses for

448
00:20:24.880 --> 00:20:28.180
not doing updates, a lot of people put the
updates off, they wait for it to happen,

449
00:20:28.180 --> 00:20:30.050
and that's just a recipe for disaster.

450
00:20:30.050 --> 00:20:33.325
So you wanna make sure you get in
there and you do those updates.

451
00:20:33.325 --> 00:20:36.635
Get the system put back the way it
needs to be, the way that it's fixed.

452
00:20:36.635 --> 00:20:37.865
And now you're protected and you're safe.

453
00:20:37.865 --> 00:20:40.315
You'll have the best
experience with your computer.

454
00:20:40.315 --> 00:20:40.935
>> All right, Don.

455
00:20:40.935 --> 00:20:43.102
Well, we've talked a lot
about updates today.

456
00:20:43.102 --> 00:20:46.650
Obviously the importance of them,
we can't harp on that enough.

457
00:20:46.650 --> 00:20:50.382
Always a good policy to, if you can,
just set it to that automatic update,

458
00:20:50.382 --> 00:20:51.817
let the system do it for you.

459
00:20:51.817 --> 00:20:54.019
Automation, it's why we have
computers anyway, right Don?

460
00:20:54.019 --> 00:20:54.826
>> Yep, absolutely.

461
00:20:54.826 --> 00:20:57.007
>> All right,
well hopefully we haven't missed anything.

462
00:20:57.007 --> 00:20:57.652
You have anything else you wanna add here?

463
00:20:57.652 --> 00:20:58.822
>> No that's it.

464
00:20:58.822 --> 00:21:01.530
>> All right, well hopefully you guys
out there have enjoyed this episode

465
00:21:01.530 --> 00:21:03.428
>> We thank you for watching, signing for

466
00:21:03.428 --> 00:21:05.737
ITProTV, I've been your
host Daniel Lowrie.

467
00:21:05.737 --> 00:21:06.559
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

468
00:21:06.559 --> 00:21:07.915
>> And we'll see you next time.

469

You know when you get a new computer and

So, if you're writing documents,

00:00:44.290 --> 00:00:47.710
taking photos,
Where do you put all that stuff?

00:00:47.710 --> 00:00:49.850
Put it on the storage
inside of your system.

00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:53.860
And fortunately in the Windows 8 world and

00:21:55.180 --> 00:22:00.210
And it takes less space than doing
an actual second copy of your data.

480
00:22:00.210 --> 00:22:03.280
So, by doing that,
we can get more room out of our drive.

481
00:22:03.280 --> 00:22:05.970
The problem is to do that,
it has to do a mathematical operation and

482
00:22:05.970 --> 00:22:07.580
it's doing it in software.

483
00:22:07.580 --> 00:22:11.180
And any time you do something in software
like that, it means it's slower.

484
00:22:11.180 --> 00:22:14.930
So if we choose parity, it's gonna slow
down our disc operations on the drive.

485
00:22:14.930 --> 00:22:17.870
Not a giant amount, but it is gonna
slow it down enough to be annoying if

486
00:22:17.870 --> 00:22:20.090
you're doing something like video editing.

487
00:22:20.090 --> 00:22:24.125
So if you want parity you're really better
off doing a hardware raid controller.

488
00:22:24.125 --> 00:22:25.965
Which a lot of motherboards,
a lot of laptops,

489
00:22:25.965 --> 00:22:28.245
they have that built into them
if you got more than one drive.

490
00:22:28.245 --> 00:22:30.135
It's not useful if you
only have one drive.

491
00:22:30.135 --> 00:22:33.365
All right, I'm going to go ahead and
choose a two way mirror, right.

492
00:22:33.365 --> 00:22:38.260
Now, as I choose these options you might
notice down here, my storage sizes.

493
00:22:38.260 --> 00:22:39.040
Okay.

494
00:22:39.040 --> 00:22:42.340
I've got three 512 gig drives.

495
00:22:42.340 --> 00:22:46.150
So, if I do no redundancy,
I end up with 1.49, or basically one and

496
00:22:46.150 --> 00:22:48.220
a half- terabytes of storage.

497
00:22:48.220 --> 00:22:49.500
That's the pool it's about to create.

498
00:22:50.800 --> 00:22:54.910
If I choose a two way mirror,
it's gonna store my data twice.

499
00:22:54.910 --> 00:22:57.520
So what happens to my one and
a half terabytes?

500
00:22:57.520 --> 00:22:59.400
It gets divided in half.

501
00:22:59.400 --> 00:23:02.050
So now I'm down to 760 gigs of storage.

502
00:23:02.050 --> 00:23:04.250
And if I do a three way.

503
00:23:04.250 --> 00:23:07.090
Well, I get 0 gigs of storage.

504
00:23:07.090 --> 00:23:07.690
It dies out.

505
00:23:07.690 --> 00:23:08.530
Why is that?

506
00:23:08.530 --> 00:23:10.200
Well, I don't have enough space.

507
00:23:10.200 --> 00:23:12.380
They're telling me I don't have
enough room to do three and

508
00:23:12.380 --> 00:23:14.210
still have a reasonable
amount of data available.

509
00:23:14.210 --> 00:23:14.970
So I need more.

510
00:23:14.970 --> 00:23:16.770
I'd need a fourth drive to do that.

511
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:17.480
All right?

512
00:23:17.480 --> 00:23:22.200
But with two-way I can do it, and I just
loose a decent amount of my data, right?

513
00:23:22.200 --> 00:23:26.380
I can also choose parody, and you'll see
where I only loose a third of that data.

514
00:23:26.380 --> 00:23:28.750
And so
I still have one terabyte available, so

515
00:23:28.750 --> 00:23:32.540
parody takes less space than
the two-way mirror, okay?

516
00:23:32.540 --> 00:23:34.350
So I need to choose what's best for
me, but

517
00:23:34.350 --> 00:23:36.810
I am gonna loose some storage
by doing this two-way mirror.

518
00:23:36.810 --> 00:23:37.940
All right.

519
00:23:37.940 --> 00:23:39.160
I'll go ahead and choose to create it now.

520
00:23:39.160 --> 00:23:40.180
Notice what it says about the size.

521
00:23:40.180 --> 00:23:41.452
This is the maximum.

522
00:23:41.452 --> 00:23:44.185
I can set it to be smaller,
maybe I just want to create a 500GB drive,

523
00:23:44.185 --> 00:23:47.164
that'll leave some extra room,
i could create another storage space with.

524
00:23:47.164 --> 00:23:51.889
But you can actually set it to be Bigger
than the pool capacity, all right.

525
00:23:51.889 --> 00:23:54.660
I can set it to three terabytes.

526
00:23:54.660 --> 00:23:57.070
Now why would they let me
set it to three terabytes,

527
00:23:57.070 --> 00:23:59.970
if I don't actually have three terabytes
and I can't make it redundant?

528
00:23:59.970 --> 00:24:03.530
Well, as it starts to fill up,
I might wanna come and

529
00:24:03.530 --> 00:24:05.360
add more hard drives later on.

530
00:24:05.360 --> 00:24:09.680
And you can add hard drives to the pool
and now it can grow to three terabytes.

531
00:24:09.680 --> 00:24:11.750
And I don't have to change my system,
I just add the drives.

532
00:24:11.750 --> 00:24:15.291
And it will do it automatically, right,
so that's kind of a neat feature.

533
00:24:15.291 --> 00:24:19.719
Versus if I set it to that
766 it was defaulting to, or

534
00:24:19.719 --> 00:24:23.689
670, whatever it was defaulting to, right?

535
00:24:23.689 --> 00:24:27.291
Then at that point, if I add more drives,
I'm gonna have to go and

536
00:24:27.291 --> 00:24:31.040
expand that partition, and
that's gonna require some work.

537
00:24:31.040 --> 00:24:32.560
So we can set it to be bigger.

538
00:24:32.560 --> 00:24:35.140
I'll set mine to, well, I don't wanna
do three terabytes, that's too big.

539
00:24:35.140 --> 00:24:36.780
Let's just say it's one terabyte,

540
00:24:36.780 --> 00:24:39.930
which is bigger than the actual
space that's available.

541
00:24:39.930 --> 00:24:43.676
All right, now if I actually eat up
all that space, it's going to act

542
00:24:43.676 --> 00:24:47.292
like the drive is full even though
it thinks that its got more room so

543
00:24:47.292 --> 00:24:49.372
it is smart enough to recognize that.

544
00:24:49.372 --> 00:24:52.343
But we can create it and put it in place,
or, you know, if I want to put it back to

545
00:24:52.343 --> 00:24:55.335
the default, I think I can just switch
off, it's not going to remember is it?

546
00:24:55.335 --> 00:24:56.676
All right, let me just drop it back.

547
00:24:56.676 --> 00:25:00.459
All right, so now I'm back,
I'm healthy, things should be good,

548
00:25:00.459 --> 00:25:05.419
actually it's saying my specified maximum,
oh 766 terabytes is pretty impressive,

549
00:25:05.419 --> 00:25:09.950
let me change that back down to gigabytes,
we'll get that created.

550
00:25:09.950 --> 00:25:14.980
All right, it's gonna build the storage
space for me and it's gonna format it.

551
00:25:14.980 --> 00:25:19.380
And now that it's done, when I browse
to my explorer, what do I see?

552
00:25:20.810 --> 00:25:22.180
A 760 gig iDrive, all right.

553
00:25:23.190 --> 00:25:25.240
As an end user,
that's a normal hard drive to me.

554
00:25:25.240 --> 00:25:27.290
I don't treat it any different,
it's my iDrive.

555
00:25:27.290 --> 00:25:29.530
I can browse through,
I can put data in there.

556
00:25:29.530 --> 00:25:32.800
And any time I write data in there,
Windows in the background is saying,

557
00:25:32.800 --> 00:25:34.130
let me make a second copy of this.

558
00:25:34.130 --> 00:25:35.470
It's making a duplicate.

559
00:25:35.470 --> 00:25:38.040
And that way if one hard drive fails,
I'll survive.

560
00:25:38.040 --> 00:25:41.420
And if hard drive fails, I'll still have
my iDrive, and I can browse right into it,

561
00:25:41.420 --> 00:25:44.510
it'll still be 760 gigs,
I'll can still get at my data.

562
00:25:44.510 --> 00:25:48.360
Right, the end user doesn't
necessarily see this anymore, but

563
00:25:48.360 --> 00:25:49.310
we get the benefit of it.

564
00:25:50.360 --> 00:25:52.975
And you can monitor the health right
back here in the storage spaces panel,

565
00:25:52.975 --> 00:25:54.940
I'll see my storage space is healthy.

566
00:25:54.940 --> 00:25:58.675
Looks like everything is up, and I can see
the physical discs that are involved in it

567
00:25:58.675 --> 00:26:02.325
if one of them has failed I'll see
which one and be able to take action.

568
00:26:02.325 --> 00:26:06.685
So all that's right there, storage spaces
are a type of local storage just like

569
00:26:06.685 --> 00:26:09.103
a regular hard drive,
they're just redundant.

570
00:26:09.103 --> 00:26:11.256
And they're kind of
Microsoft proprietary too so

571
00:26:11.256 --> 00:26:14.948
we're really just gonna work inside of
the Microsoft environment but that's fine,

572
00:26:14.948 --> 00:26:18.191
if you're on a Windows system you can
use these, it really does work well.

573
00:26:18.191 --> 00:26:21.883
>> I love the fact that you can have
all those drives in one spot but

574
00:26:21.883 --> 00:26:24.513
it only shows up as one
drive to the end user.

575
00:26:24.513 --> 00:26:28.501
You have that whole experience of,
oh did I put that on the F drive or

576
00:26:28.501 --> 00:26:31.610
the I drive or the J drive,
I don't remember.

577
00:26:31.610 --> 00:26:35.150
So, taking that large capacity,
putting it on One Drive.

578
00:26:35.150 --> 00:26:38.270
And of course if you have the redundancy
built in there, it's also a nice feature.

579
00:26:38.270 --> 00:26:39.230
Having that One Drive,

580
00:26:39.230 --> 00:26:43.055
I've noticed with my users, they tend
to appreciate that a little more.

581
00:26:43.055 --> 00:26:44.010
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

582
00:26:44.010 --> 00:26:46.280
Even if you have to pay to
get that extra storage,

583
00:26:46.280 --> 00:26:50.170
I appreciate One Drive just because
Microsoft worries about that redundancy.

584
00:26:50.170 --> 00:26:52.580
If a drive fails,
they're the ones who have to fix it.

585
00:26:52.580 --> 00:26:54.280
It's not me going and ordering a drive.

586
00:26:54.280 --> 00:26:55.270
They take care of it.

587
00:26:55.270 --> 00:26:56.510
There's a benefit to that, and

588
00:26:56.510 --> 00:27:00.280
if it costs you a few bucks a year,
it's worth it to me not to worry about it.

589
00:27:00.280 --> 00:27:03.910
But, if you've got data that can't go to
the cloud, just huge volumes of it or

590
00:27:03.910 --> 00:27:04.890
it's private data or

591
00:27:04.890 --> 00:27:08.240
whatever, something like Storage Spaces
can really solve that problem for you.

592
00:27:08.240 --> 00:27:10.580
So, great options that are available for
us there.

593
00:27:10.580 --> 00:27:11.190
Right?

594
00:27:11.190 --> 00:27:15.760
Now, on one of the slides, I had a chance
to pick what file system I wanted to use.

595
00:27:15.760 --> 00:27:17.870
And, I want to talk about each of
those because they are on the exam,

596
00:27:17.870 --> 00:27:18.940
they're important to know.

597
00:27:18.940 --> 00:27:22.010
But we're kinda out of time for this
segment, so I'll tackle that in part two.

598
00:27:22.010 --> 00:27:25.360
There's a few other bits and pieces
about storage that we want to address.

599
00:27:25.360 --> 00:27:29.030
But this is probably a good spot for
us to kind of wrap this up.

600
00:27:29.030 --> 00:27:32.500
But definitely stay tuned for part two,
where we'll jump into those files systems,

601
00:27:32.500 --> 00:27:36.590
and kinda see what the differences between
each one, and how they handle their data.

602
00:27:36.590 --> 00:27:38.090
>> All right, excellent stuff Don.

Thanks for watching everyone.

We're gonna go ahead and

We got a chance to take a look at local

14
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:46.280
spaces all inside of Windows 8, different
ways of storing your data on the system.

15
00:00:46.280 --> 00:00:50.278
And one thing that we touched on super
briefly, but really didn't get into,

16
00:00:50.278 --> 00:00:53.420
were the different file
systems that were available.

17
00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:56.820
So, inside of Windows,
when you use a hard drive,

18
00:00:56.820 --> 00:01:01.040
we have to tell Windows how we want
to store the data on the drive.

19
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:04.820
If you think about it, a file is
broken up into ones and zeros, right?

20
00:01:04.820 --> 00:01:07.130
There are like binary bits inside of it,
right?

21
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:11.160
And so every file, you might see a
picture, or you might see a document, but

22
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:13.920
a computer sees a string of ones and
zeroes.

23
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:16.770
And it has to write those ones and
zeroes to the hard drive.

24
00:01:16.770 --> 00:01:20.720
And the hard drive is
usually magnetic media.

25
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:22.780
It could be SSD,
which is a little different, but

26
00:01:22.780 --> 00:01:24.250
it's usually magnetic media.

27
00:01:24.250 --> 00:01:25.610
And so it's got to write these ones and

28
00:01:25.610 --> 00:01:28.820
zeros to that media so
that it can go and recall.

29
00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:33.680
Well, in order for it to find
where your data is, in order for

30
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:37.290
it to retrieve the data and get it back
for us, it has to have a way to locate it.

31
00:01:37.290 --> 00:01:40.850
It has to have a way to know how
the data is written to the disk

32
00:01:40.850 --> 00:01:42.350
so it can get it back.

33
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:47.154
And over the years, different operating
system vendors have found different ways

34
00:01:47.154 --> 00:01:51.974
to do it, so on a Windows machine, data is
stored one of a couple of different ways.

35
00:01:51.974 --> 00:01:53.940
In the Linux world,
you've got a good eight or

36
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:56.470
nine different file systems
that can be used there.

37
00:01:56.470 --> 00:01:59.840
In the Apple world, you have two or three
different file systems that can be used.

38
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:02.140
And they're all different,
they're all separate.

39
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:05.680
So, Windows can't necessarily
read an Apple drive, and

40
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:08.370
an Apple machine can't necessarily
read a Linux drive, and so on.

41
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:11.500
But there are a lot that are compatible,
where they can read each others drives,

42
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:13.130
and that's pretty cool stuff.

43
00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:18.240
So, we wanna make sure we take advantage
of the right file system for us, so

44
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:23.360
when you get a new hard drive and you go
to format is, to get it ready, right?

45
00:02:23.360 --> 00:02:24.670
We need to make some choices.

46
00:02:24.670 --> 00:02:27.346
Now, that word format,
a lot of people throw that word around and

47
00:02:27.346 --> 00:02:29.107
don't necessarily know what that means.

48
00:02:29.107 --> 00:02:32.020
When we say we format a drive,
what pops in to your mind?

49
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:33.960
Well, people think of erasing the drive.

50
00:02:33.960 --> 00:02:35.930
Well, I wanna format it,
that means I'm want to erase it.

51
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:37.180
And that would be true, right?

52
00:02:37.180 --> 00:02:39.860
If you format a drive you
are going to erase it.

53
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:42.700
But what you're really doing
when you format a drive,

54
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:46.060
is you're laying on it
what's called a file system.

55
00:02:46.060 --> 00:02:49.449
And the file system is usually
made of two parts, okay?

56
00:02:49.449 --> 00:02:51.394
The first part is your data, your data,

57
00:02:51.394 --> 00:02:54.945
when you save that document,
you save that picture, you save whatever,

58
00:02:54.945 --> 00:02:59.170
it's gotta be written to the hard drive
somewhere, that's your data, right?

59
00:02:59.170 --> 00:03:02.850
And so
that's going on top of this file system.

60
00:03:02.850 --> 00:03:07.310
And on the other part,
is the information about your file.

61
00:03:07.310 --> 00:03:08.528
Every file has information.

62
00:03:08.528 --> 00:03:09.420
It's something, right?

63
00:03:09.420 --> 00:03:13.250
It has a file name at a minimum,
you can't have a file without a file name.

64
00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:13.906
So you got a file name.

65
00:03:13.906 --> 00:03:14.570
Its got a size,

66
00:03:14.570 --> 00:03:19.590
its got a date that it was modified,
its got a date that it was created.

67
00:03:19.590 --> 00:03:22.120
These are things that we
need to know about a file.

68
00:03:22.120 --> 00:03:23.626
On some advanced file systems,

69
00:03:23.626 --> 00:03:27.097
you have all sorts of crazy things
like permissions or metadata, right?

70
00:03:27.097 --> 00:03:31.500
Think about a MP3 where it has who
the artist was and the album and all that.

71
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:34.210
That's information about your file.

72
00:03:34.210 --> 00:03:38.800
Some file systems can store that data,
some file systems can't.

73
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:42.420
So in the example of music, most file
systems don't know if you have music or

74
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:45.220
not and so that music metadata is
stored in the music file itself.

75
00:03:46.500 --> 00:03:48.310
But, a file name.

76
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:49.870
Every file has a file name.

77
00:03:49.870 --> 00:03:53.800
So when you create a file system,
it creates a special little place,

78
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:57.340
like a database, usually it's right
at the beginning of the drive.

79
00:03:57.340 --> 00:04:00.160
And it says, I'm gonna create
a list of all the file names that

80
00:04:00.160 --> 00:04:01.690
are on this system.

81
00:04:01.690 --> 00:04:05.194
And if you have directories, like folders,
those folders aren't real, they don't

82
00:04:05.194 --> 00:04:08.703
actually exist anywhere inside of the hard
drive, they're just kind of references.

83
00:04:08.703 --> 00:04:12.337
And it says, I'm gonna say there's
this folder, and inside of it,

84
00:04:12.337 --> 00:04:14.020
there's these files.

85
00:04:14.020 --> 00:04:17.020
And each file has a pointer

86
00:04:17.020 --> 00:04:19.900
to somewhere on the hard drive
where the actual data is stored.

87
00:04:20.960 --> 00:04:24.020
So, how is that structured,
how is that database structured,

88
00:04:24.020 --> 00:04:25.660
how is the data written to the hard drive?

89
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:27.980
How do we find it retrieve it and
change it?

90
00:04:27.980 --> 00:04:29.340
That's what your file system dictates.

91
00:04:30.778 --> 00:04:33.431
Now, to kinda understand
where we are today,

92
00:04:33.431 --> 00:04:37.989
we're gonna need to jump back in time a
bit, kinda go back to the beginning of how

93

read NTFS, but they can't write to it.

323
00:15:38.220 --> 00:15:40.490
They can't write to it because
they haven't licensed it and

324
00:15:40.490 --> 00:15:42.940
that would be them using the technology
and it would corrupt the disc.

325
00:15:42.940 --> 00:15:43.630
Right?

326
00:15:43.630 --> 00:15:44.820
Or they'd have to pay licensing.

327
00:15:44.820 --> 00:15:45.810
One or the other.

328
00:15:45.810 --> 00:15:46.410
So they don't.

329
00:15:46.410 --> 00:15:50.760
So Apple and Linux, they can read NTFS but
they can't write to it.

330
00:15:50.760 --> 00:15:52.930
Windows machines can read and
write to it all day long.

331
00:15:52.930 --> 00:15:54.410
Right?
It's a great file system.

332
00:15:54.410 --> 00:15:56.380
It's what most of us
are going to default to.

333
00:15:56.380 --> 00:15:57.050
Right.

334
00:15:57.050 --> 00:16:02.592
Now, what happens when the day
comes that 16 exabytes is nothing?

335
00:16:02.592 --> 00:16:05.618
16 exabytes is tiny, and
we're complaining cuz our cell phones, and

336
00:16:05.618 --> 00:16:08.505
I'm saying hey Daniel,
can I borrow your 16 exabyte thumb drive?

337
00:16:08.505 --> 00:16:12.324
And you give it to me, and I hook it up
And he's telling me about the deal he got

338
00:16:12.324 --> 00:16:15.336
on them for $12 a piece on Amazon,
or whatever, right?

339
00:16:15.336 --> 00:16:17.660
When that day comes,
we need something bigger.

340
00:16:18.790 --> 00:16:21.330
And Microsoft is already working
on that something bigger.

341
00:16:21.330 --> 00:16:24.135
You'll see little hints of it
spread throughout Windows, but

342
00:16:24.135 --> 00:16:25.885
it's not ready for prime time yet.

343
00:16:25.885 --> 00:16:26.945
But it is on the MTA exam.

344
00:16:27.985 --> 00:16:32.765
They have a new file system called
the Resilient File System, or ReFS.

345
00:16:34.345 --> 00:16:39.010
ReFS, the Resilient File System
is the replacement for NTFS.

346
00:16:39.010 --> 00:16:43.250
And what it's designed to do
is to scale much larger and

347
00:16:43.250 --> 00:16:45.780
to have resiliency or
journaling built into it.

348
00:16:45.780 --> 00:16:47.260
Now, what is journaling?

349
00:16:47.260 --> 00:16:52.300
Journaling says, when I write to the hard
drive, I don't write to the actual file.

350
00:16:52.300 --> 00:16:54.150
I write to a different place and

351
00:16:54.150 --> 00:16:58.210
only when I'm 100% done do I
actually write to the file.

352
00:16:58.210 --> 00:17:00.380
So that means if I lose power
half way through a write,

353
00:17:00.380 --> 00:17:02.780
the original file's still intact.

354
00:17:02.780 --> 00:17:04.030
So when I bring it back up,

355
00:17:04.030 --> 00:17:06.790
I don't have disk corruption
which is what FAT32 got us.

356
00:17:06.790 --> 00:17:10.290
Or NTFS got that sorry, but
also don't have file corruption.

357
00:17:10.290 --> 00:17:11.900
It gives me full resiliency.

358
00:17:11.900 --> 00:17:15.460
ReFS is very protective of that and it has
some other technologies built into it to

359
00:17:15.460 --> 00:17:19.570
provide redundancy and other things, so
ReFS is very powerful from that respect.

360
00:17:21.150 --> 00:17:27.830
And they've sized it for data that's
considered absurd for the future.

361
00:17:27.830 --> 00:17:32.457
And so basically it's,
this is where it gets really odd.

362
00:17:32.457 --> 00:17:38.296
A maximum volume size of one yottabyte,
a yottabyte, a yb.

363
00:17:38.296 --> 00:17:42.456
Now, you might familiar with gigabyte or
gbs,

364
00:17:42.456 --> 00:17:47.150
terabytes, tbs, exabytes ebs, a yottabyte.

365
00:17:47.150 --> 00:17:52.210
Now, for each of these,
a terabyte is 1000 gigabytes.

366
00:17:53.880 --> 00:17:56.970
An exabyte is 1000 terabytes.

367
00:17:56.970 --> 00:18:01.480
But a yottabyte is far
bigger than 1000 exabytes.

368
00:18:01.480 --> 00:18:09.280
A yottabyte is actually 1 billion,
billion with a b, 1 billion terabytes.

369
00:18:09.280 --> 00:18:09.920
Massive.

370
00:18:09.920 --> 00:18:11.917
Or 1 million exabytes.

371
00:18:11.917 --> 00:18:14.494
It's huge.

372
00:18:14.494 --> 00:18:18.800
And what they're saying is, ten years
from now, a yottabyte is gonna be

373
00:18:18.800 --> 00:18:22.551
considered an insane amount of data,
and ReFS is ready for it.

374
00:18:22.551 --> 00:18:25.740
So that's gonna be the final
system of the future.

375
00:18:26.950 --> 00:18:30.234
Now, as far as individual file size,
there's no limit, it can be

376
00:18:30.234 --> 00:18:34.120
as large as your yottabyte array is or
whatever, that you've built for ReFS.

377
00:18:34.120 --> 00:18:41.434
So there's no file size limit, but
the volume size is limited to 1 yottabyte.

378
00:18:41.434 --> 00:18:42.212
Oh, you know what?

379
00:18:42.212 --> 00:18:45.149
Sorry, let me correct myself.

380
00:18:45.149 --> 00:18:46.739
I need to make sure this is accurate.

381
00:18:46.739 --> 00:18:49.479
On NTFS, there's no file size limit.

382
00:18:49.479 --> 00:18:50.956
It's limited to your volume.

383
00:18:50.956 --> 00:18:53.776
But there is actually
a file size limit in ReFS.

384
00:18:53.776 --> 00:18:55.435
It's just really gigantic.

385
00:18:55.435 --> 00:18:58.128
It's 16 exabytes.

386
00:18:58.128 --> 00:19:01.835
So you have one yottabyte
as the maximum volume size.

387
00:19:01.835 --> 00:19:05.489
16 exabytes as the maximum
individual file size.

388
00:19:05.489 --> 00:19:08.531
So if you have 1 file,
you gotta cap it off at 16 exabytes.

389
00:19:08.531 --> 00:19:09.877
A massive amount of data.

390
00:19:09.877 --> 00:19:12.993
>> Well, I know I'm gonna run out of
that super soon, it's a really big deal,

391
00:19:12.993 --> 00:19:13.929
they should fix that.

392
00:19:13.929 --> 00:19:14.637
It's so frustrating.

393
00:19:14.637 --> 00:19:16.807
>> Yeah, so
basically that's the solution there,

394
00:19:16.807 --> 00:19:19.036
that's what they've come up with for
the future.

395
00:19:19.036 --> 00:19:22.203
Now when we're working in Windows,
what does this mean to us, well,

396
00:19:22.203 --> 00:19:25.434
it might not mean much, but if you ever
go to write a file to a hard drive.

397
00:19:25.434 --> 00:19:27.242
And the file's 3 gigs in size and
you look and

398
00:19:27.242 --> 00:19:29.775
the hard drive has got plenty of
space on it and it won't write.

399
00:19:29.775 --> 00:19:31.680
And says the driver's full.

400
00:19:31.680 --> 00:19:34.950
It might be that you're
trying to write a 3 gig file

401
00:19:34.950 --> 00:19:37.200
to a file system that
doesn't support 3 gigs.

402
00:19:37.200 --> 00:19:38.910
So we need to understand
the files that are available.

403
00:19:39.960 --> 00:19:42.690
Let me show you what it's like
here in the disc manager.

404
00:19:42.690 --> 00:19:45.153
So, I'm in my computer
management screen here, and

405
00:19:45.153 --> 00:19:48.124
I've got one hard drive that I've
divided up into four pieces.

406
00:19:48.124 --> 00:19:50.004
See, how I've got FAT?

407
00:19:50.004 --> 00:19:53.430
Fat 32, NTFS and ReFS.

408
00:19:53.430 --> 00:19:56.380
So, I got these different guys
kind of floating about here.

409
00:19:56.380 --> 00:19:58.660
All on one physical hard drive
I've just created partitions.

410
00:20:00.200 --> 00:20:04.620
When you create a drive inside of Windows,
it defaults to NTFS.

411
00:20:04.620 --> 00:20:05.630
That's the one that it wants.

412
00:20:06.890 --> 00:20:08.410
But you can choose other ones.

413
00:20:08.410 --> 00:20:11.970
But the options kind of change
based on the size of your drive.

414
00:20:11.970 --> 00:20:15.198
So, for example,
I've got this storage space down here.

415
00:20:15.198 --> 00:20:17.009
It's 768 gigs.

416
00:20:17.009 --> 00:20:20.849
If I try and format that,
when I go to format it,

417
00:20:20.849 --> 00:20:25.554
I get a couple of choices,
NTFS and ReFS, and that's it.

418
00:20:25.554 --> 00:20:27.492
I don't get any other choices.

419
00:20:27.492 --> 00:20:29.059
Why is that?

420
00:20:29.059 --> 00:20:34.179
Well, at this size, well, actually this
one is limited because of storage spaces.

421
00:20:34.179 --> 00:20:37.848
But, it's too big for
some of the other file systems.

422
00:20:37.848 --> 00:20:42.538
If I take this drive here, this is
a 100 gig drive, it's only a 100 gigs.

423
00:20:42.538 --> 00:20:48.660
If I go to format that,
I can choose between well, NTFS and ReFS.

424
00:20:48.660 --> 00:20:49.820
Those are the two that I can choose,

425
00:20:49.820 --> 00:20:53.050
and if you're trying this at home,
ReFS won't show up by default.

426
00:20:53.050 --> 00:20:54.900
You actually have to edit
a Registry key to turn that one,

427
00:20:54.900 --> 00:20:56.660
because it's not ready for prime time.

428
00:20:56.660 --> 00:20:59.200
Microsoft doesn't really want
you running it right now.

429
00:20:59.200 --> 00:21:01.850
You can, but
you have to basically turn it on.

430
00:21:01.850 --> 00:21:04.332
I'll put the steps to turn it on in
the show notes, so you can have it.

431
00:21:04.332 --> 00:21:07.211
You don't need to know that for the exam.

432
00:21:07.211 --> 00:21:09.325
But if I take a look at some
of these smaller drives,

433
00:21:09.325 --> 00:21:10.612
like here's a 32 gig drive.

434
00:21:10.612 --> 00:21:15.012
32 gigs,
that falls under the limit of FAT32.

435
00:21:15.012 --> 00:21:17.195
Well, actually let me
visit that real quick.

436
00:21:17.195 --> 00:21:19.691
Because when I talk about FAT32
what did I say the limit was?

437
00:21:19.691 --> 00:21:24.618
I said the limit was 2 terabytes, but I
didn't see FAT32 with formatting this one,

438
00:21:24.618 --> 00:21:28.618
but on this one when I go to format it,
there's FAT32 in my choices.

439
00:21:28.618 --> 00:21:30.708
Why do I see it here and
not on the other ones?

440
00:21:30.708 --> 00:21:34.075
Well, that's because
Microsoft made the decision.

441
00:21:34.075 --> 00:21:39.141
In software, they said they don't want
you formatting a disk over 32 gigs,

442
00:21:39.141 --> 00:21:40.229
with that 32.

443
00:21:40.229 --> 00:21:43.595
They want you to switch up to NTFS,
that's what they want you to use.

444
00:21:43.595 --> 00:21:45.348
But you still can do it.

445
00:21:45.348 --> 00:21:48.122
You can download third party utilities
that will let you format the disk,

446
00:21:48.122 --> 00:21:49.969
you can actually do it
from the command line too.

447
00:21:49.969 --> 00:21:54.568
Where you can format a larger disk all
the way up to 2 terabytes as FAT32 if

448
00:21:54.568 --> 00:21:55.229
you want.

449
00:21:55.229 --> 00:21:56.238
But here in the UI it limits it.

450
00:21:56.238 --> 00:21:58.675
So that's why FAT32 wasn't
showing up on the other guys.

451
00:21:58.675 --> 00:22:01.303
But I see it here because the drive is

452
00:22:01.303 --> 00:22:04.991
under the 32 gig limit
that Microsoft imposed.

453
00:22:04.991 --> 00:22:09.066
If I go to an even smaller drive,
this one is 4 gigs.

454
00:22:09.066 --> 00:22:15.056
If I go to format it,
now I get FAT in addition to FAT32.

455
00:22:15.056 --> 00:22:20.720
So now I'm getting a drive that's able to
have more options because it's smaller.

456
00:22:20.720 --> 00:22:22.000
It's within the limits of FAT.

457
00:22:22.000 --> 00:22:26.060
So, Microsoft is actually checking for
us, what's compatible.

458
00:22:26.060 --> 00:22:29.350
Can you use this file system on
that particular type of disk?

459
00:22:29.350 --> 00:22:31.290
And sometimes you can,
sometimes you can't.

460
00:22:31.290 --> 00:22:33.900
For example, NTFS, NTFS has

461
00:22:33.900 --> 00:22:39.420
like something like 4 megabytes in data
that it eats up with just its table alone.

462
00:22:39.420 --> 00:22:43.180
And so if you're trying to format a drive
that's under 4 megabytes, NTFS won't work.

463
00:22:43.180 --> 00:22:45.480
Well, who has something that's
under 4 megabytes today?

464
00:22:45.480 --> 00:22:50.480
If you had a floppy disk, you can't format
a floppy disk NTFS, but FAT32 works.

465
00:22:50.480 --> 00:22:52.180
So it's actually checking for
that four and

466
00:22:52.180 --> 00:22:54.140
only showing us the file
systems that we need.

467
00:22:55.280 --> 00:22:59.059
Now, the trick for
an end user is once a disk is formatted,

468
00:22:59.059 --> 00:23:01.851
here in Explorer, they all look the same.

469
00:23:01.851 --> 00:23:05.362
I named them so I'd remember what they
were, so I knew which one is FAT32 and

470
00:23:05.362 --> 00:23:08.116
which one isn't, but
when you come in here and look at them,

471
00:23:08.116 --> 00:23:09.593
like if I go into this FAT drive.

472
00:23:09.593 --> 00:23:11.967
Here, this is my E drive and
I've got a file in it,

473
00:23:11.967 --> 00:23:14.017
I can start working with the copying data.

474
00:23:14.017 --> 00:23:17.198
I've got a 2 gig file sitting
right here on this FAT drive, and

475
00:23:17.198 --> 00:23:19.253
that's cuz FAT can handle a 2 gig file.

476
00:23:19.253 --> 00:23:22.594
But if I go into some of my other
drives like my FAT32 drive,

477
00:23:22.594 --> 00:23:24.175
I've got a 4 gig file here.

478
00:23:24.175 --> 00:23:28.768
And if I were to try and copy that and
put that on to my FAT32 drive, I'm sorry,

479
00:23:28.768 --> 00:23:30.839
FAT drive, what's gonna happen?

480
00:23:30.839 --> 00:23:32.105
Well, the files too big.

481
00:23:32.105 --> 00:23:33.658
It's not gonna be able to write that,

482
00:23:33.658 --> 00:23:36.190
it's gonna exceed what this
file system can handle.

483
00:23:36.190 --> 00:23:39.920
And so when you go to place it, it's
gonna say there's not enough free space.

484
00:23:39.920 --> 00:23:41.950
There might actually be enough free space,
but

485
00:23:41.950 --> 00:23:44.300
it can't handle the file size that large.

486
00:23:44.300 --> 00:23:46.980
That's what it bumps into and
you start getting errors like these.

487
00:23:46.980 --> 00:23:49.780
So that's why it's important that as
administrators that we understand the file

488
00:23:49.780 --> 00:23:51.545
systems, so we know when we can see it.

489
00:23:51.545 --> 00:23:55.253
Now, on mine, I named them so
I could remember it just for the show.

490
00:23:55.253 --> 00:23:59.420
But in real-life land an easy way to
figure out is if you just right-click

491
00:23:59.420 --> 00:24:03.510
on a drive and choose Properties, it'll
tell you how it's formatted right there.

492
00:24:03.510 --> 00:24:09.090
So this drive, this one, might be called
Sales, and this one might be called

493
00:24:09.090 --> 00:24:13.640
Marketing, and I might have others that
are called Human Resources, or whatever.

494
00:24:13.640 --> 00:24:15.920
As I store data for my company.

495
00:24:16.980 --> 00:24:20.190
And so, here they are, and
just however we named them.

496
00:24:20.190 --> 00:24:21.230
Notice how I typed those.

497
00:24:21.230 --> 00:24:23.660
I typed them lower case, but
then it went capitalized.

498
00:24:23.660 --> 00:24:27.610
And that's because FAT and
FAT32 don't store case for a label.

499
00:24:27.610 --> 00:24:30.340
But things like NTFS do.

500
00:24:30.340 --> 00:24:34.280
So, if I type this out like that.

501
00:24:34.280 --> 00:24:35.500
It's not gonna make it capitalized.

502
00:24:35.500 --> 00:24:37.130
It's different features for
different file systems.

503
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:39.080
We have to kinda be aware of that.

504
00:24:39.080 --> 00:24:42.310
But now, I don't know which
one is formatted which way.

505
00:24:42.310 --> 00:24:46.758
And so I can just pull up the properties
and I'll see it right there, NTFS.

506
00:24:46.758 --> 00:24:51.158
So to the exam, we need to be aware of
the four different file system types.

507
00:24:51.158 --> 00:24:55.437
FAT, FAT32, NTFS, and ReFS.

508
00:24:55.437 --> 00:24:58.814
We need to know that FAT and
FAT32 are the old way.

509
00:24:58.814 --> 00:25:02.215
And that we'll probably only use FAT32
on removable media that we're moving

510
00:25:02.215 --> 00:25:04.306
between systems because
of its compatibility.

511
00:25:04.306 --> 00:25:07.673
But that it's got that 32 gig
limit in software in Windows.

512
00:25:07.673 --> 00:25:09.287
You need to know that.

513
00:25:09.287 --> 00:25:12.095
And then, NTFS,
that's the one we wanna use.

514
00:25:12.095 --> 00:25:15.648
On all of our systems, for operating
systems, removal media, wherever you can,

515
00:25:15.648 --> 00:25:17.750
use NTFS,
that's where you get the full power.

516
00:25:17.750 --> 00:25:21.129
But in the future, ReFS is coming.

517
00:25:21.129 --> 00:25:25.050
Know that it's not ready yet, but it will
be the next file system that comes along,

518
00:25:25.050 --> 00:25:26.747
and that's what we're gonna see.

519
00:25:26.747 --> 00:25:28.684
So those are the takeaways
that we need to know for

520
00:25:28.684 --> 00:25:30.393
the exam on those different file systems.

521
00:25:30.393 --> 00:25:31.369
>> Awesome stuff, Don.

522
00:25:31.369 --> 00:25:34.692
Now, I would say that that's not
just good news for the exam, but

523
00:25:34.692 --> 00:25:38.451
also good stuff that you need to
memorize just as you're getting into IT.

524
00:25:38.451 --> 00:25:40.028
This is stuff that's very applicable.

525
00:25:40.028 --> 00:25:44.153
You are gonna run into those people that
have something that has been formatted

526
00:25:44.153 --> 00:25:48.295
FAT32 and they're trying to copy over
a file that's way too large for that.

527
00:25:48.295 --> 00:25:50.242
And they're gonna call your desk, and say,

528
00:25:50.242 --> 00:25:53.164
I don't know why this file isn't
coming out, plenty of space, and

529
00:25:53.164 --> 00:25:56.907
it's not making it over and you're like,
let's check that formatted file system and

530
00:25:56.907 --> 00:26:00.135
see how you've got it set up,
maybe you're running into a problem there,

531
00:26:00.135 --> 00:26:02.725
definitely had my share of those
actions from time to time.

532
00:26:02.725 --> 00:26:03.990
>> Absolutely.

533
00:26:03.990 --> 00:26:07.264
>> Don, well,
have we covered all our bases on this one?

534
00:26:07.264 --> 00:26:07.950
>> Yeah, that's it.

That's we don't need a part
three on this one, I promise.

536
00:26:09.912 --> 00:26:11.269
>> [LAUGH] Well, excellent.

537
00:26:11.269 --> 00:26:13.371
Hopefully, you guys have
enjoyed this episode.

538
00:26:13.371 --> 00:26:14.369
Thanks for watching.

539
00:26:14.369 --> 00:26:16.052
Signing off for IT Pro TV.

00:26:16.052 --> 00:26:17.446
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

541
00:26:17.446 --> 00:26:18.271
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
