all right?

523
00:23:53.488 --> 00:23:56.507
So these are both going to
the same physical printer,

524
00:23:56.507 --> 00:23:59.780
to the same physical print device, right?

525
00:23:59.780 --> 00:24:04.459
But now I've got two software
representations of the same printer.

526
00:24:04.459 --> 00:24:07.640
And they're shared out and
I can go an change the permissions.

527
00:24:07.640 --> 00:24:10.570
I can modify the permissions
on the executives printer.

528
00:24:10.570 --> 00:24:14.720
So, if I go into my printer properties,
and I go to sharing, I could set, or

529
00:24:14.720 --> 00:24:15.550
go into security, sorry.

530
00:24:15.550 --> 00:24:18.360
I could set it so that only
executives could print to this one.

531
00:24:18.360 --> 00:24:20.840
And then I could go to the other one and
set it so

532
00:24:20.840 --> 00:24:22.540
that employees can go to that one.

533
00:24:22.540 --> 00:24:25.350
So now I've kind of restricted
them to the separate printers.

534
00:24:25.350 --> 00:24:29.900
And once that's done, I can start
modifying the settings on these printers.

535
00:24:29.900 --> 00:24:34.750
And so on the executives printer,
I might go into my printer properties and

536
00:24:34.750 --> 00:24:39.820
I might start changing certain things
in here like their priority,okay.

537
00:24:39.820 --> 00:24:42.960
When you set a priority, I just
pulled up the printer properties and

538
00:24:42.960 --> 00:24:43.720
went to the advanced tab.

539
00:24:43.720 --> 00:24:48.190
You can set the priority and I can say
that executives are priority number one.

540
00:24:48.190 --> 00:24:51.440
And then I can take employees and
set them to priority 100.

541
00:24:51.440 --> 00:24:56.841
And now, when an executive prints, their
job will jump to the front of the line.

542
00:24:56.841 --> 00:25:00.178
Now it won't interrupt somebody
who's in the process of printing,

543
00:25:00.178 --> 00:25:03.530
like it won't stop on page seven and
let the executive cut in.

544
00:25:03.530 --> 00:25:06.450
But as soon as that job finishes,
the executive is next, right.

545
00:25:06.450 --> 00:25:08.000
So we can kind of prioritize like that.

546
00:25:08.000 --> 00:25:10.750
These are ways that you can manipulate it
so that different people have different

547
00:25:10.750 --> 00:25:13.360
experiences, even though they're
printing to the same physical printer.

548
00:25:13.360 --> 00:25:16.620
And there's a lot of other stuff you can
do to treat these settings like setting

549
00:25:16.620 --> 00:25:19.000
them to be only available
from certain times.

550
00:25:19.000 --> 00:25:21.700
So, if you have an employee who's
coming in on the weekends and printing,

551
00:25:21.700 --> 00:25:24.850
you could cut that out real easy
by limiting it just to work hours.

552
00:25:24.850 --> 00:25:28.480
And now if they wanna print some of that
extra junk like Daniel was talking about,

553
00:25:28.480 --> 00:25:30.730
you'll see it cuz they gotta to
do it during work hours right?

554
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:34.245
So those are advanced settings that
we can define on the printer and

555
00:25:34.245 --> 00:25:35.930
they apply to the shares.

556
00:25:35.930 --> 00:25:39.627
And you can define more than one share
based on the same physical printers.

557
00:25:39.627 --> 00:25:43.700
Kind of a neat little technique there to
really customize a print environment.

558
00:25:43.700 --> 00:25:45.190
>> Very cool stuff, Don.

559
00:25:45.190 --> 00:25:48.799
I guess have we thought of anything else
that we need to talk about when it comes

560
00:25:48.799 --> 00:25:49.900
to these printers?

561
00:25:49.900 --> 00:25:52.070
>> Well, on printers, that's it.

562
00:25:52.070 --> 00:25:55.775
I do have more I need to talk about it,
I said at the beginning of the show there

563
00:25:55.775 --> 00:25:58.640
was some advanced stuff behind file
sharing I wanted to talk about.

564
00:25:58.640 --> 00:26:02.560
I kind of rambled on too long,
Daniel, so, you know what that means?

565
00:26:02.560 --> 00:26:03.673
>> Part three?
>> Part three, yeah.

566
00:26:03.673 --> 00:26:04.844
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

567
00:26:04.844 --> 00:26:06.632
we're definitely gonna do
a part three on this one,

568
00:26:06.632 --> 00:26:08.964
because I need to get to the advanced
stuff on sharing permissions.

569
00:26:08.964 --> 00:26:10.138
So yeah, let's wrap this one up and

570
00:26:10.138 --> 00:26:11.870
we'll just pick up with
another episode from here.

571
00:26:11.870 --> 00:26:12.690
>> Awesome.

572
00:26:12.690 --> 00:26:14.620
Well hopefully,
you guys have enjoyed this episode.

573
00:26:14.620 --> 00:26:16.570
Printing, sharing is something
that you might wanna do.

574
00:26:16.570 --> 00:26:17.950
We're gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

575
00:26:17.950 --> 00:26:21.140
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lawry.

576
00:26:21.140 --> 00:26:21.790
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

577
00:26:21.790 --> 00:26:23.278
>> And we'll see you next time.

578

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don break down the technologies behind NTFS and shared permissions. Don demonstrates how to set the permissions on a folder for a user to access, modify, and create new documents. He also explains the ability to block or allow permissions to trickle down.
episodes.title: File and Print Sharing Part 3

WEBVTT

1

2
00:00:11.630 --> 00:00:13.746
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3

welcome to another fantastic
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.910 --> 00:00:18.090

5
00:00:18.090 --> 00:00:20.740
Here with me, none other than Mr.
Don Pezet himself.

6
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:21.660
How's it going today, Don?

7
00:00:21.660 --> 00:00:22.720
>> It is going great, Daniel.

8
00:00:22.720 --> 00:00:24.830
Back for the unexpected.

9
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:27.000
Part three of File and Printer Sharing.

10
00:00:27.000 --> 00:00:29.170
I've rambled on for too long,
for several episodes now.

11

So we're going into
part three on this one.

12
00:00:30.900 --> 00:00:34.380
We need to take a look at some of
the advanced things that go on behind

13
00:00:34.380 --> 00:00:36.680
the scenes when it comes to file and
printer sharing.

14
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:39.410
And this is the episode for
us to tackle it.

15
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:40.050
I promise, this time.

16

We'll wrap it up after this,
and we won't do a part four.

17
00:00:42.163 --> 00:00:43.361
>> Shut your fat yap.

18
00:00:43.361 --> 00:00:44.220
[LAUGH]
>> I know.

19
00:00:44.220 --> 00:00:45.335
[LAUGH] Famous last words.

20
00:00:45.335 --> 00:00:47.552
>> That's right.
>> In the previous two episodes,

21
00:00:47.552 --> 00:00:51.808
we took a look at sharing folders on
the network, and we took a look at sharing

22
00:00:51.808 --> 00:00:55.540
printers on the network, and
And it worked out really good.

23
00:00:55.540 --> 00:00:59.700
But one thing that we didn't
talk about was sharing folders

24
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:01.950
just between users on the same computer,
right?

25
00:01:01.950 --> 00:01:03.140
What if it's not on the network?

26
00:01:03.140 --> 00:01:04.840
What if I don't even have a network?

27
00:01:04.840 --> 00:01:08.340
I have a computer that I
share with other people, and

28
00:01:08.340 --> 00:01:10.990
I wanna have a folder that's
available to both of us.

29
00:01:10.990 --> 00:01:14.070
Well, there's a couple of
easy ways to do that, right?

30
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:17.510
But the key thing to remember is
that when you're sharing folders

31
00:01:17.510 --> 00:01:21.000
just locally on a machine to
another user on the same machine,

32
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:23.950
it doesn't actually use
the Windows share system.

33
00:01:23.950 --> 00:01:26.390
So that share system that we
saw with the permissions and

34
00:01:26.390 --> 00:01:29.840
all that,
that only applies to network users.

35
00:01:29.840 --> 00:01:32.030
If somebody comes and
sits down right on your computer and

36
00:01:32.030 --> 00:01:35.680
they login, those permissions,
they don't apply.

37
00:01:35.680 --> 00:01:39.210
So somebody might have read-only
permissions on the network, and

38
00:01:39.210 --> 00:01:42.920
they sit down on your computer and
now they've got a lot more access.

39
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:46.210
So we need to be able to control that
access right on a single machine and

40
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:47.010
that's something that we didn't

41
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:49.000
se on the earlier episodes that
I wanted to point out here.

42
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:50.230
And there's some important reasons why.

43
00:01:50.230 --> 00:01:52.510
You'll see a little later in the episode.

44
00:01:52.510 --> 00:01:54.530
But let's just get started
with that kinda scenario.

45
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:57.340
I wanna create a folder right here on
this machine and make it available for

46
00:01:57.340 --> 00:01:58.920
more than one person, all right.

47
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:01.590
Now, I've already got folders
inside of my user profile.

48
00:02:01.590 --> 00:02:02.530
We've seen those, right.

49
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:06.300
In my Documents folder,
I had that Security folder I shared out,

50
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:10.520
and I made that available on
the network this is in my user profile.

51
00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:14.500
And I don't want to necessarily want other
users to have to browse into my profile to

52
00:02:14.500 --> 00:02:15.640
get to this stuff.

53
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:19.350
So I might want create a folder that's
somewhere that's a little more central to

54
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:21.140
my network, to my computer.

55
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:27.010
If I go to this PC I've got my C
drive right, this is my hard drive.

56
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:28.780
Or I've got other hard
drives on my system,

57
00:02:28.780 --> 00:02:32.910
like I've got my F drive down here that
is NTFS, so I can browse into that and

58
00:02:32.910 --> 00:02:36.780
create a folder there, or browse into
my C drive and create the folder there.

59
00:02:36.780 --> 00:02:38.410
I'll do it on my C drive.

60
00:02:38.410 --> 00:02:43.969
So I'll come in here just say New > Folder
and I'll call this Shared Documents.

61
00:02:43.969 --> 00:02:47.898
Right, so these are gonna be ones that I
wanna make available to everybody in my

62
00:02:47.898 --> 00:02:48.860
computer, okay.

63
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:51.112
And these might be sales documents,
or whatever.

64
00:02:51.112 --> 00:02:55.648
Now, when you create that folder,
you can start putting documents in there.

65
00:02:55.648 --> 00:02:57.954
So I can start adding in whatever I want.

66
00:02:57.954 --> 00:03:02.070
I'll just add some fake documents in
here to get something in there, and

67
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:06.060
each one of these are being created and
put in the folder.

68
00:03:06.060 --> 00:03:09.770
So in theory, I should be able to log in
as another user, browse in this folder and

69
00:03:09.770 --> 00:03:11.430
access the files, right?

70
00:03:11.430 --> 00:03:13.470
Well, not necessarily.

71
00:03:13.470 --> 00:03:15.480
When you create files in your hard drive,

72
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:18.170
there's a different set of
permissions that are applied.

73
00:03:18.170 --> 00:03:20.970
We have what are called NTFS permissions.

74
00:03:20.970 --> 00:03:24.422
When you format your hard drive as NTFS,
this is default in Windows,

75
00:03:24.422 --> 00:03:26.100
you get a permissions sublayer.

76
00:03:26.100 --> 00:03:29.335
And what that permissions sublayer
does is when you create a folder,

77
00:03:29.335 --> 00:03:31.210
we're gonna make it just for you.

78
00:03:31.210 --> 00:03:32.850
It's your folder, right?

79
00:03:32.850 --> 00:03:35.320
And we're going to give it
certain permissions that

80
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:37.220
make sure that you have access.

81
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:39.070
And other people might get access.

82
00:03:39.070 --> 00:03:42.220
When you create a folder, it actually
does what's called inheritance.

83
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:44.510
It has to get some default
permissions from somewhere.

84
00:03:44.510 --> 00:03:48.030
And it gets those permissions from
whatever folder it's inside of.

85
00:03:48.030 --> 00:03:52.940
So, I just created a Shared Documents
folder on my C drive.

86
00:03:52.940 --> 00:03:56.519
So, whatever permissions are assigned
to the C drive itself were used as

87
00:03:56.519 --> 00:03:57.995
the default for this folder.

88
00:03:57.995 --> 00:03:59.897
It inherited those permissions, and

89
00:03:59.897 --> 00:04:02.570
then it added it to make
sure that I had access.

90
00:04:02.570 --> 00:04:04.550
Okay, now, I'm always gonna
have access to this folder,

91
00:04:04.550 --> 00:04:06.900
because I'm the owner,
I'm the one who made it.

92
00:04:06.900 --> 00:04:11.130
Every file, every folder on
an NTFS drive has an owner.

93
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:12.230
And you can see it.

94
00:04:12.230 --> 00:04:15.520
If you pull up the properties
of that folder, or file,

95
00:04:15.520 --> 00:04:20.280
it's the same thing on a file,
and you go to the Security tab,

96
00:04:20.280 --> 00:04:23.430
here's where we see those default
permissions that were applied.

97
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:25.660
So who got access to this?

98
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:30.340
And you'll see Authenticated Users,
System Administrators,

99
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:33.490
administrators are always
gonna have access, and

100
00:04:33.490 --> 00:04:37.470
then Users, DONPEZET-PC/users, some of my
regular users got access to it, right?

101
00:04:37.470 --> 00:04:38.590
Now I might not want that.

102
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:39.980
I might need to change that.

103
00:04:39.980 --> 00:04:44.160
But these are the default permissions
that came from the parent drive,

104
00:04:44.160 --> 00:04:46.110
that came from that C drive.

105
00:04:46.110 --> 00:04:50.600
And later on here and so my default,
my users have access to the C drive.

106
00:04:50.600 --> 00:04:51.920
They don't have full control of it.

107
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:54.030
See how right is not checked?

108
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:55.940
But they do have access to read it.

109
00:04:55.940 --> 00:04:57.470
A regular user can browse the hard drive.

110
00:04:57.470 --> 00:04:59.080
They have that permission.

111
00:04:59.080 --> 00:05:01.570
So I might want to tweak these and
change them a bit but

112
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:04.470
these permission were
inherited from that parent.

113
00:05:04.470 --> 00:05:09.650
And if I go down here to advanced here,
I can see who the owner is.

114
00:05:09.650 --> 00:05:11.670
And I'm the owner, Don Pezet, right there.

115
00:05:11.670 --> 00:05:13.600
I created it, so I'm the owner.

116
00:05:13.600 --> 00:05:16.220
No matter what happens,
I will always have access.

117
00:05:16.220 --> 00:05:18.270
You can't lock out the owner.

118
00:05:18.270 --> 00:05:20.740
Even if I empty out the permissions
list and take everybody out,

119
00:05:20.740 --> 00:05:22.410
I'll still have access, cuz I'm the owner.

120
00:05:22.410 --> 00:05:25.550
All right, if you're
an administrator on a computer and

121
00:05:25.550 --> 00:05:27.810
you're locked out of a folder, well,

122
00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:30.560
technically as an administrator
you can never get locked out.

123
00:05:30.560 --> 00:05:34.520
Because as an administrator, you can
pull up the properties of that folder,

124
00:05:34.520 --> 00:05:38.250
you can go to the advanced security
settings, and you can change the owner.

125
00:05:38.250 --> 00:05:40.830
You can make yourself the owner and
now you have access.

126
00:05:40.830 --> 00:05:43.440
So if the user ever tries to lock you out,
an administrator can get in.

127
00:05:43.440 --> 00:05:45.420
You can't lock out an administrator.

128
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:47.620
This is called seizing ownership.

129
00:05:47.620 --> 00:05:49.860
You might have to seize
ownership to get back in, but

130
00:05:49.860 --> 00:05:52.700
you can do that cuz you're
an administrator, all right?

131
00:05:52.700 --> 00:05:55.740
Now, as a regular user,
a regular user can lock themselves out.

132
00:05:55.740 --> 00:05:57.150
A regular user can't seize ownership.

133
00:05:57.150 --> 00:05:58.810
They don't have that permission,
all right?

134
00:05:58.810 --> 00:06:01.940
So, a regular user could potentially
lock themselves out of their own

135
00:06:01.940 --> 00:06:05.580
file if they were in here messing around
with their permissions, all right.

136
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:08.450
But there's plenty of times that we
do wanna mess with these permissions.

137
00:06:08.450 --> 00:06:10.270
If I go back out here,

138
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:15.140
I can set these things by what group
people are in, or who they are.

139
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:16.030
Authenticated users,

140
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:19.390
that just means anybody who's logged in
with a user name and password, right?

141
00:06:19.390 --> 00:06:23.550
Anybody who's successfully
authenticated network or local, right?

142
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:27.500
Users, this is saying users that have
an account right here on this machine.

143
00:06:27.500 --> 00:06:29.190
So those are a little bit different but

144
00:06:29.190 --> 00:06:32.220
those are covering most
of my users at this case.

145
00:06:32.220 --> 00:06:35.490
if I just want it to be me and Jane,
I don't want anyone else to have access,

146
00:06:35.490 --> 00:06:40.100
just Jane and myself and that's it,
I can edit these permissions and

147
00:06:40.100 --> 00:06:41.530
I can start to change them.

148
00:06:41.530 --> 00:06:44.090
Right?
I can manipulate who has access.

149
00:06:44.090 --> 00:06:47.310
I might wanna remove authenticated users,
right?

150
00:06:47.310 --> 00:06:50.290
But if I do that, see the warning I get?

151
00:06:50.290 --> 00:06:52.010
If you look at the settings
on those permissions,

152
00:06:52.010 --> 00:06:54.700
see how these check marks
are grayed out a little bit?

153
00:06:54.700 --> 00:06:58.130
And that's because these permissions
aren't actually set on this folder.

154
00:06:58.130 --> 00:07:01.318
I'm inheriting them from the parent,
from the C drive.

155
00:07:01.318 --> 00:07:08.210
So I can add to these but
I can't take away those permissions.

156
00:07:08.210 --> 00:07:09.030
But I want to take away.

157
00:07:09.030 --> 00:07:10.970
I want to set these my way.

158
00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:14.090
Well, if I want to do that I've
got to override the inheritance.

159
00:07:14.090 --> 00:07:15.773
They call it blocking the inheritance.

160
00:07:15.773 --> 00:07:20.546
And you might have noticed the option when
I went under advanced the option is right

161
00:07:20.546 --> 00:07:23.730
down here to replace all
child object permissions with

162
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:26.380
inheritable permissions from this object.

163
00:07:26.380 --> 00:07:29.310
So it's basically saying
replace whatever I've done here

164
00:07:29.310 --> 00:07:30.580
with the stuff from above, right?

165
00:07:30.580 --> 00:07:32.450
This would put it back to
the way it is now, but

166
00:07:32.450 --> 00:07:35.060
right above that disable inheritance.

167
00:07:35.060 --> 00:07:37.380
I can turn off the inheritance, and

168
00:07:37.380 --> 00:07:40.380
now I can fully customize
these permissions, right?

169
00:07:40.380 --> 00:07:42.930
Now, when you turn it off it asks you,
do you wanna just

170
00:07:42.930 --> 00:07:45.610
copy the permissions that are there so
you have a starting point?

171
00:07:45.610 --> 00:07:48.390
Or do you wanna remove them all and
start from scratch?

172
00:07:48.390 --> 00:07:49.830
And I usually like to convert it.

173
00:07:49.830 --> 00:07:51.460

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain some of the ways that you can secure data using common encryption methods. The start with Microsoft's built-in solutions; the Encrypting File System(EFS) and BitLocker which can be used to encrypt either single files or entire hard drives. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don describe the concept of authentication and explain the methods commonly used to that end. Methods like passwords, biometrics, and multifactor authentication are detailed as well as smart cards and Windows Rights Management Services. They also introduce you to the many types of malware that threaten computer systems; both how to differentiate and how to avoid them. Some of the malware types discussed are viruses, trojan horses, spyware, and adware. Then they show you how to avoid, and if need be, disinfect these hazards by utilizing antivirus solutions like Windows Defender.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore one of Microsoft's cloud based computer management suites called Intune. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain Identity services inside a Microsoft environment, specifically Windows Server Active Directory, Azure Active Directory, and Federation Services. They also explain the concept and implementation of using a Microsoft Account, which allows you to be you no matter what device you're signed into. They also discuss the idea of business data access. Accessing company data from anywhere, especially outside of the business network, is commonplace anymore. Microsoft has deployed solutions like the Company Portal in Intune, Work Folders in Active Directory, and Azure RemoteApp to enable that access to the end user.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the concept of the BYOD, or Bring Your Own Device, environment. As more and more personal devices are being used to access private resources, we can use Microsoft solutions to help safely integrate those devices and users. Here we look at methods like virtualization, dynamic access control policies, and Windows Rights management to help make that goal a reality.

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Wes introduce Windows RT. They discuss some of the limitations to managing Windows RT devices in an enterprise network through traditional mechanisms. They demonstrate how to manage a Windows RT device through Microsoft Intune. They explore the administrative roles that can be delegated in Microsoft Intune. They also take a look at the compliance and configuration policy processing and explain the results of policy conflicts.
